;For a taste of all three, drive 70 minutes north up the ;A;171 to Teesside, a struggling industrial region. Ben Houchen, the Conservative mayor of this traditionally Labour region, is fighting for re-election. His offer to voters is one of unapologetic economic interventionism. Almost Â£560m ($700m) of public money has been pledged to overhaul a 1,800-hectare site by the Tees in an effort to turn the graveyard of a former steelworks into something productive. Lord Houchen even bought a loss-making airport on the basis that executives could fly in to invest while Teessiders could fly out to spend the proceeds on the Med. â€œDirigismeâ€ is the idea that the state can orchestrate an economy; â€œHouchismeâ€ is a shrunken version, with a local economy bossed by a regional big man.

;The scheme has been dogged by accusations of mismanagement and worse. ;This is part of the point of devolution. The British government and in particular its mighty Treasury is good at stopping sins of commission. White elephants do exist but they are rare, since so many projects are aborted moments after conception. As a result, however, sins of omission are common. Devolution means more things will be tried because of decisions made by local politicians. But that will, inevitably, lead to mistakes.

;;

;Having a right mayor

;

;At the moment, a place like Scarborough is stuck in limbo. Central government has neither the guts to let it die nor the will to try to resuscitate it. A mayor will neither change the weather (it is still woolly-hat weather in spring) nor return the town to its Victorian pomp. But someone might end up cleaning the layer of grime and seagull droppings that covered the window in Bagehot's filthy hotel room. Whether that is a good use of taxpayer money is for votersâ€”or at least the fraction of them who bother to vote in local electionsâ€”to decide.

;

;Devolution is a long-term punt that local politicians will, on the whole, make better decisions about their area than national ones. Boosters insist a virtuous circle will kick in: more powers will attract higher-calibre candidates, which will lead to more scrutiny, which will mean better policy. Everyone in British politics has signed up to the gamble. The price in the short term? Whatever a 413-room Victorian hotel in Scarborough goes for these days. ;â– ;

;T. John Ward, Marshall's federal judge from 1999 to 2011, is responsible for the town's puzzling popularity. Patent cases are technical. Judges must referee the sharing of sensitive source code, for example: plaintiffs argue it will prove their case; defendants resist, fearing their secrets will leak. They also interpret what a patent's words actually mean, which can be â€œoutcome determinativeâ€, says Mark Siegmund, a patent litigator in Waco. Cases can also take years to get to trial.

;Mr Ward learned that Northern California's court had implemented local rules to build what lawyers call â€œcertaintyâ€â€”a predictable processâ€”into the unwieldy cases. He adopted similar ones, tweaking them to prioritise speed. Litigants reached trial in half the time it took in California. Around the same period, â€œit also happened that there was an explosion of patent-troll litigation,â€ says Paul Gugliuzza of Temple University, referring to plaintiffs who own bad patents and seek quick and cheap settlements. By the mid-2010s Mr Ward's successor, Rodney Gilstrap, had about a quarter of the country's patent cases.

;;A Dirty War: A Russian Reporter in Chechnya. ;By Anna Politkovskaya. ;Harvill Press; 368 pages; Â£18.99.;

;The second Chechen war followed two calamities. One was the chaotic invasion in 1999 of neighbouring Dagestan by a Chechen warlord, Shamil Basayev. That attack enraged the Kremlin. The second was a series of deadly bombings of tower blocks in cities across Russia. The Kremlin blamed Chechen terrorists for the blasts and so had an excuse to try, once more, to subdue the region. ;Anna Politkovskaya; was a fiercely independent Russian journalist who produced scathing coverage of the Kremlin's corruption and rightsæ»¥ç”¨èŒæƒã€‚ She described how the second campaign shifted from air strikes to the removal of Chechnya's government and, eventually, a counter-insurgency operation. Politkovskaya, who was murdered in Moscow in 2006, showed how Mr Putin used the war to focus public attention on himself. Her writing considers the ruined lives of ordinary Chechens, from elderly people abandoned in a care home to young men tortured during Russian â€œcleansingâ€ missions. The book ends with a scene in a hospital which is characteristic of her powerful reporting: vivid descriptions and interviews with individual Chechens shift attention from high politics to the victims of war. ;;From Conquest to Deportation: The North Caucasus under Russian Rule. ;By Jeronim Perovic. ;Hurst; 480 pages; Â£65.;

;

;Chechnya has a bloody history. Jeronim Perovic, a historian, traces the story of Russian rule in the North Caucasus, notably in Chechnya, beginning with Russian attempts in the 19th century to conquer the region and culminating in the Caucasian War. That decades-long campaign consumed, at one point, a sixth of the imperial budget. He explains how the Tsars and the Soviet Union recruited regional elites to crack down on local dissent. The climax of the book tells how Josef Stalin, fearing Chechens would collaborate with invading Germans in the second world war, banished over 600,000 people to Central Asia. The deported Chechens and other minorities were allowed back only in 1957. Among those displaced were Dudayev, then an infant, and the parents of Akhmad Kadyrov, who was born in exile in Kazakhstan. The memory of deportation remains painfully tangible for many Chechens. For the region's modern political exiles it is a lived reality.

;

;;The Cossacks and Other Stories. ;By Leo Tolstoy. ;Penguin; 528 pages; Â£10.99.;

;

;Leo Tolstoy has a claim to be one of Chechnya's favourite Russians. The writer spent the early 1850s as an artilleryman in the North Caucasus and lends his name to a village in Chechnya, Tolstoy-Yurt. Another settlement hosts a museum dedicated to his memory, funded partly by Ramzan Kadyrov, intended to foster Chechen affections for Russia. Tolstoy set two of his stories largely in Chechnya. â€œThe Cossacksâ€ he wrote early in his career; the other, â€œHadji Muratâ€, he wrote at the end. The first opens with a description of a Cossack soldier who shamefully kills a young Chechen, sparking a cycle of violence that leads to a dreadful conclusion. The second is a portrait of a historical rebel who broke from Imam Shamil, a resistance leader, and forged an alliance with the Russians. Tolstoy's version of Hadji Murat's life depicts the divided loyalties and political intrigues driving those who fought over Chechnya in the Caucasian War. A thoughtful critique of imperial aggression, â€œHadji Muratâ€ gives a glimpse of the Caucasus seen through Russian eyes.

;

;;Welcome to Chechnya. ;Directed and produced by David France.

;

;Chechnya is a dark mirror of the Russian state. Mr Putin's regime is militaristic and ultra-conservative. So too is Mr Kadyrov's, though he makes distinctive appeals to Chechen tradition. Mr Kadyrov is especially ;hostile; to gay people, who face violent persecution and whose existence he denies. David France, an American filmmaker, posed as a tourist in order to make a film, â€œWelcome to Chechnyaâ€, much of which he recorded on an iPhone. Following a network of activists who smuggle gay Chechens out of the republic, the documentary includes several escape attempts. Mr France's approach gives the film a claustrophobic feel, capturing something of the republic's repressive atmosphere. He uses deepfakes to disguise his vulnerable subjects' identities. The result is a reflection on repression and a tribute to activists who are determined to forge a better Chechnya. Read our full review of â€œ; Welcome to Chechnya;â€.

;; I;;T IS NO; accident that Israel and Iran are on the precipice of war. It is the result of long-standing agendas devised by misguided policymakers on both sides.
;
;Start with Iran.å‡ åå¹´æ¥ï¼Œå…¶å…¬å¼€å®£ç§°çš„å¯¹ä»¥è‰²åˆ—çš„ä»‡æ¨å’Œå°†è¿™ä¸ªå›½å®¶ä»åœ°å›¾ä¸ŠæŠ¹å»çš„å†³å¿ƒä¸€ç›´æ˜¯å…¨åŠ›ä»¥èµ´çš„ã€‚ One struggles for a metaphor: Captain Ahab and the white whale?

;

;Iran's policy towards Israel has been geared towards two things it feels it needs to stand nose-to-nose with its adversary.é¦–å…ˆæ˜¯ä»ä»¥è‰²åˆ—é‚»è¿‘åœ°åŒºå‘åŠ¨æ”»å‡»çš„èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚ä¼Šæœ—å¸Œæœ›èƒ½å¤Ÿé€šè¿‡å¹¿æ³›çš„è¢­å‡»æ¥å¨èƒä»¥è‰²åˆ—ï¼Œä»æ»‹æ‰°è¢­å‡»åˆ°å¤§è§„æ¨¡åœ°é¢å’Œå¯¼å¼¹è¢­å‡»ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œå…¶åœ¨å™åˆ©äºšå’Œé»å·´å«©çš„ä»£ç†äººéå¸¸é‡è¦ã€‚ The second perceived requirement is a nuclear-weapons system to match Israel's. Iran is yet to achieve that goal, and one can only guess at how its leaders would think about and wield the capability once it was acquired.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;George Washington believed that one country's extravagant hatred of another is sure to distort its foreign and domestic affairs in ways that get it into trouble. Iran exemplifies this point. Yet for the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic Republic, hostility to Israel validated both Iran's foreign policy and its domestic policy. The current crisis demonstrates vividly who has the better of the argument.
;
;Israel, for its part, has followed a strategic doctrine dubbed â€œthe campaign between the warsâ€. The idea, driven by the recognition that major wars no longer produced decisive victories, was to maintain pressure on adversaries between such conflicts to deter them from starting one. The problem with this doctrine, long apparent outside Israel's security bubble, is now clear: it is virtually guaranteed to ignite such wars. As I have written before, one can never know whether the next bomb dropped will trigger a large-scale response. The Israelis have exploited Syrian airspace for years to attack Iran and its friends as they tried to construct a front against Israel in the Golan Heights and resupply Hizbullah's arsenal in Lebanon. In their campaign, the Israelis dropped that one bomb too many.
;
;These are not problems that America can solve. Its diplomatic intervention in a Middle East crisis works when regional adversaries value its help and America has a workable strategy. These conditions are, of course, reciprocal. America could work with Anwar Sadat and Menahem Begin, and with Yasser Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin. Forget about Binyamin Netanyahu and Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Israel's and Iran's current leaders. Their obstinacy is obvious. It needs stressing, nevertheless, given critics' claims that the current crisis reflects a failure of American strategy, or the suggestion that some clever formula emerging from the White House will bring peace.
;
;Iran has now selected the worst of all possible ploys in response to the twin pressures it was facing: to take a strong stand against Israel's campaign against Hamas in Gaza, and to respond to Israel's attack on the Iranian consulate in Syria. Iran had been handling the Gaza challenge well by limiting itself to political support for Palestinian militants and leaving kinetic resistance to Iranian proxies. But Iran's direct drone-and-missile attack on Israel has arguably turned Iran and its Palestinian partners into villains. Although it caused little damage and only one casualty, the unmistakable message was that such an attack, if larger and on shorter notice, could cause far greater destruction. It was ominous enough to call for a serious Israeli reply.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For Israel's current government, pleas from America, the ;EU; and Gulf Arab states to refrain from responding in kind probably sound foolish. As Naftali Bennett, a former Israeli prime minister, has pointed out, the Iranians must have expected, and certainly desired, many deaths. Thus, he argues, the response should be scaled to what might have been rather than what actually was.

;

;If Israel does retaliate, as looks likely, it must decide not only how big to go but where: should the attack be aimed at Iran's proxies, targets within Iran or both? To complicate matters, Iran is shovelling large quantities of small arms into the West Bank to ignite the smouldering war there between Israeli settlers and Palestinian farmers. Having asserted that it would counter any Israeli response with a larger barrage and threatened to include American targets in any subsequent attacks, Iran is either prepared to risk war or foolishly assuming it is deterring it.

;

;Concerned states have done all they could to prevent escalation. Perhaps they will succeed. But the current state of politics in Israel and Iran and the poor quality of their respective leaderships counsel only the most cautious optimism. America has sharply increased its combat power in the region in the hope of giving Iran and its client militias pause, but it is now essentially hostage to Israel's response to Iran's latest provocation. The fact remains that American and Israeli interests would be best served if focus shifted from Iran's attack back onto resolving the crisis in Gaza. This would underscore Iran's irrelevance to the core issue and perhaps incentivise Israel to take the â€œday afterâ€ problemâ€”the future of Gaza and broader Israeli-Palestinian relationsâ€”more seriously.

;

;The vexing question is how to engineer such a shift. The submerged anti-Iranian alliance broke the surface when Jordan, France and Britain joined Israel and America in countering Iran's attack. The ;EU; and the ;G;7 also condemned the Iranian attack. The ;EU; is especially irritated by Iran's informal alliance with Russia and its material support for Russia's war in Ukraine. To head off escalation, America and the ;EU; could propose a meeting of alliance members in lieu of an Israeli military response. Such a gatheringâ€”in, say, Riyadh, the Saudi Arabian capitalâ€”would be a powerful if non-kinetic rebuke to Iran. It might also encourage Israel to refocus on a swift conclusion of its campaign in Gaza, to agree on the deployment of a multinational peacekeeping force and to start co-operating with the new Palestinian prime minister, Mohammad Mustafa. Whether Mr Netanyahu and his radical cabinet would recognise the wisdom of a merely diplomatic response would, of course, remain uncertain. ;â– ;
